convert binary to decimal with mental math

Jul 12, 2015 • binary

A tutorial on how to convert binary numbers in your head.

Usefulness

While this skill isn’t terribly useful, since a quick Google search will list several sites which can perform the conversion for you, it has been known to show up in technical interview questions and it’s pretty impressive to people who don’t understand how it works.

How it works

The general idea is to move from the left side of the number to the right. Every time you shift, multiply your running total by 2, and when you hit a 1, add it to your total.

Example:

101010
^ start with 1 (total = 1)
101010
 ^ shift to the right means multiply by 2, 
 the digit is 0 so don't add anything (total = 2)
101010
  ^ shift again, multiply by 2, and then add 1 
  because there's a 1 here (total = 5)
101010
   ^ another shift, multiply by 2 (total = 10)
101010
    ^ another shift and a 1 so multiply by 2 and 
    add 1 (total = 21)
101010
     ^ last shift, multiply by 2 and we're done 
     (total = 42)

Working with fractions

Converting binary fractions is a bit harder but follows a similar pattern. The difference here is the starting point is the right side and the end is the ones place. Also, we divide by 2 instead of multiplying by 2 as we shift.

Example:

0.101
    ^ start with 1 (total = 1)
0.101
   ^ divide by 2 (total = 0.5)
0.101
  ^ divide by 2 then add 1 (total = 1.25)
0.101
^ divide by 2 and we're done (total = 0.625)
